job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Burlington, VT

cons: Vermont is an expensive state to live in.

review_title: The UVM Medical Center is a fantastic place to work!
pros: Great pay and benefits (including employee housing if available). Leadership is truly dedicated to making UVMMC a place that people want to work. Many administrative jobs are able to be performed remotely.
cons: The pandemic was difficult; there are still many travelers on staff.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Burlington, VT
pros: Teaching hospital gives you lots of opportunities to learn.
cons: Always busy and stressful and not always a lot of staff with traveling nurses

pros: My department is extremely lucky to have good leaders. I have a very flexible manager who allows me to have a flexible schedule.
cons: I am constantly overworked. Even though it’s encouraged that I take time off, I’m always worried to because of how much work I have to do. And it feels unfair to add to someone else’s workload. The organization is terrible at communicating changes to protocols so they come up as a surprise (often when you are at your busiest).

review_title: Great place to work - growth opportunities

pros: It's a job. Expect to do what you were hired for.

job_title: Registered Dental Hygienist, RDH in Burlington, VT
pros: One of the best dental offices I have ever worked for. Excellent management practices, and great crew to work with. Fabulous benefits.
cons: Some areas have heavy oversight by larger institutional system (e.g., sterilization is done at a central location at the hospital and SOPs are very specific and need to be strictly followed).

review_title: Good job and benefits low pay
job_title: Electronic Health Records Specialist in Burlington, VT

review_title: Accounting Department History at Porter, for current applicants
job_title: Senior Data Analyst in Middlebury, VT
pros: The Clinical Staff and HR staff were progressive, caring, talented and trained. "Front of the House" personnel, were outstanding [Nurses, Doctors, clinical staff - all patient-facing staff are included in this "Pros", including Nutrition and Dietary and Environmental Staff.
cons: My comments are for prospective employees to know the history of the accounting department, which I wish I had known, when I took the position. I sincerely hope the processes have changed and the personnel who developed and supported it, has changed. That being said, the Accounting department when I arrived in 2020 was the biggest sh1tshow I ever worked for in my 15 years of corporate and non-profit work. Accounting management was unskilled in best accounting practices, leadership and people skills, or did not care, to say the least. I tried to transfer out, but when the Controller found out, they "COVID" laid me off". before I was able to accomplish an internal transfer. This happened within a matter of days. It was brutal and traumatic. The personnel I worked with with fossils who had been in the accounting department [ after another nearly 100% turnover, I was told at the interview, when I asked. But the ones remaining, were probably the ones who caused the turnover in the first place. it was either their first "real" job, or they were a fossil of the organization who "got things done" but apparently no one cared about HOW they were done [the sh1tsh0w} No formal management training observed here, let alone progressive management skills that I was accustomed to. My experience at Porter hospital Finance department was traumatic, and judging from the turnover in the last seven years, I am not the only one. I ended up retiring from accounting field after this position. I truly hope for healthcare access in Middlebury, that the Accounting department was wiped clean and internal processes evaluated and changed to even approach best practices. None observed while I was there.

pros: The benefits are great and easily access healthcare
cons: Overworked employees, no support from higher ups, no opportunities to use PTO

pros: They care about their employees.
cons: They afford the nurses' union too much respect.

pros: -Great Boss to work under!

review_title: Solid place to work, pays slightly better than most EMS jobs out there.

pros: You will meet some great people who also work in the network. Health insurance is great. Benefits are decent. Offer decent CTO
cons: Horrible pay with not much opportunity for raises - Does not match with the cost of living in the state at all. Bully culture is very much a thing. Upper management does not do anything about it seeing they are usually the worse of the bullies. Favouritism is horrible in departments. Off site parking, which at times you have to get to the parking area over an hour early just so you can catch a bus, which may or may not be on time. Not much room for advancement - Mainly lateral moves with no pay change. Overall lack of respect for anyone who is not a doctor or specialist.

review_title: If you’re in it for the money… healthcare isn’t for you

You can get a job in any entry level position in Burlington for more or the same pay. They don't even provide coffee or plastic utensils in the breakroom!

Zero support for neurodiversity, although there is some headway being made for LGBTQ folks. People of color are superficially supported but sometimes treated unkindly by staff and if yhe staff are needed their behaviors may be ignored. It is hard to rise in the ranks as a person of color.

review_title: Does not care about staff retention, which shows
job_title: Licensed Nurse Assistant in Burlington, VT
pros:
Depending on where you work, the culture can be good. They seem to be trying to phase out the "eat their young"/culture of shame and intimidation. Encourage LNAs and RNs to work collaboratively and view patient care as a team sport.

Multiple opportunities to join learning/development groups and committees.
cons:
They only care about patient safety so far as licensing requirements and legality forces them to. RNs only have "safe" staffing ratios because of the union. LNAs are NOT unionized here and it shows. They do not allot for enough LNAs to care for a reasonable amount of patients, consistently leaving LNAs with anywhere from 12 to 30+ patient assignments. 

Relies HEAVILY on travel nurses, does not even try to hire locally or retain the staff they have. 

Pay is abysmal. Jobs that do not require licensure pay more than this. 

Did nothing to support front line staff at the height of the COVID pandemic.

Management sends the clear message that they do not value your opinion or input. Bringing up your concerns results in retaliation down the line, and turns it around to become your problem of bad time management, etc. Completely unwilling to accept that people actually enjoy our jobs and want to do them well, but need resources to do so.

job_title: Patient Service Specialist in Burlington, VT
pros: The employees make the job tolerable
cons: Low wages and lack of communication amongst management

job_title: IS Help Desk Support Staff in Burlington, VT
pros:
The salary by far, Vermont is a very hard place to try to find a job that pays a decent wage  In the IT field,  this job started just under $26 an hour and there's plenty of opportunity for overtime!
 The other huge plus in working here is the amount of information I learned, supporting over 50 different applications each one more complex than the last  was very challenging and very satisfying at the same time!
 Most of my coworkers were amazing,  along with one of my three supervisors  Who was fantastic, I could always ask him a question and he would always help me with a smile on his face..
cons: Having two managers who absolutely do not care about the people who work in the helpdesk department, when I started working there I was told that I wouldn't feel comfortable  supporting all of the different applications for at least 6 months,  being let go just a few days shy of my 90 day review!

pros: BCBSVT. I love the population we serve. Nice Staff
cons:
Parking (parking assignments that can add up to 2 hours to your work day when you live so close to the hospital).
Low pay (very high cost of living in Vermont)
Short Staffing (both inpatient and outpatient)
Management focuses on fixing issues that are minimal instead of focusing on fixing bigger issues such as: employee retention, parking, competitive wages, decreasing the high turnover rate.
No incentives provided to employees that would make younger staff want to stay in this area: discounts on daycare, in-hospital day care services.

pros: Good to work at most days
cons: Ok to work at most days

review_title: RN Staff Nurse II, RN Case Manager
job_title: RN Case Manager in Burlington, VT
pros: Good benefits, good pay. Work load is busy but doable. Never a dull moment! Lots to learn, always can gain more experience by working here. The nurses union does an adequate job protection safe patient care. Staffing ratios are reasonable on most of the units. The cafe food is actually pretty decent and affordable. Onsite parking for eve, night and weekend shifts.
cons: Poor orientation process in this department although it was fine in other areas that I have worked. Management is so so, extremely variable from unit to unit. the overall job satisfaction of most employees is strongly tied to the manager of the unit. Scheduling can be a big dissatisfier in nursing and its no different here, lots of weekends and odd schedules if working in a unionized position. You have to take a bus from a remote parking location if working day shift.

pros: Fletcher Allen Health Care is well known as one of Vermont's largest employers.  There are a lot of growth opportunities at Fletcher Allen Health Care.  The best thing about this organization is the number of different jobs available that will open up.  Fletcher Allen encourages its employees to stick with a job for 6 months to a year before transferring to a different department, but during those 6 months to a year you can get some valuable experience for future jobs.  This place is great especially because the healthcare industry is a safe and dependable industry to be in.  Great place to work for Vermonters!
cons: The parking situation at Fletcher Allen is TERRIBLE.  Employees that work at the Main Hospital as well as University Health Care are forced to park in satellite lots and ride shuttles (school buses) to work.

review_title: Great place to work, depending on your department
pros: Great benefits, increasing the longer you work there, good work/life balance for admins, opportunities for training, great cafeteria food! Yearly performance-based raises (every year except this one, when COVID wiped out a huge chunk of our revenue stream). Senior leadership is also becoming more and more invested in educating themselves about diversity, equity, and inclusion and committed to working on various issues. This year was tough, and they put a ton of effort into being extra communicative as things changed so rapidly. (Of course, nobody's perfect, and there have been some holes). They also did temporary pay and benefit cuts for the senior leadership as much as possible to avoid any staff reductions and gave everyone an extra week's pay to help with financial pitfalls.
cons: Some departments are better than others. Physician/faculty entitlement is always present, but in varying degrees depending on your department.

review_title: Most corrupt management Team I have had the dis-pleasure to work for.
pros: Fletcher Allen is Vermonts largest hospital and one of their biggest employers.  I was excited accepting a job there, as their pay and benefits are really good.
cons:
Fletcher Allen seemed like a great place to work...at first.  Looks can be deceiving, very deceiving.  Politics rules the roost at FAHC.  Upper management is incompetent and Managers and supervisors are the most corrupt I have ever encountered. Human Resources is a joke, as they are in upper managements back pocket. There are absolutely no resources for an employee who has been wronged by management.   There is no individual thinking at all - It's their way or the highway.
Worst place, by far.... I have ever worked for.. BEWARE!!!!

pros:
It is the only hospital in the area and therefore pays the highest salaries for nurses.
Great professional and knowledgeable staff .  
Patients come to FAHC from all over VT and upper NY state.
FAHC is an academic medical center with 430 + beds and a level 1 trauma center.
cons:
There is no real clinical ladder  in place for registered nurses. 
The hospital was unionized (RN's and LPN's) recently due to a variety of issues...staffing levels, low salaries, overtime, etc.  Morale, hopefully, has increased since I left in 2006.
Working with the residents and interns can be problematic depending on your point of view......

pros: The providers I worked with were awesome and always eager to teach and encourage. I wanted to work here because UVMMC advertise themselves as an employer that encourages continued education and advancement.  However, it was nearly impossible to ever get time off to attend lectures or take classes. My supervisor rarely approved time off. I was given a lecture about how short staffed we were when I asked for time off to attend a funeral.
cons: Always short staffed. No support from the supervisor. Pay is terrible. Parking was difficult. No flexibility with scheduling to attend educational classes, funerals or any personal issues.

pros: Most of the staff is friendly and supportive, depending upon which unit you work on.  We have a nursing union within the hospital.
cons: Don't count on getting a decent raise as a nurse- the raises don't keep up with the cost of living.  There isn't much competition in the area.  You can't park on site.  You have to park at a satellite parking lot and ride in on an ancient yellow school bus.  It can add 20-30 minutes to your commute.

job_title: Lab Customer Service Representative in Burlington, VT
pros: Great benefits, pay and organization. This was by far the best job I have held in my career. I was happy to go to work every single day. Employees of this company care about patients, community and fellow co-workers.
cons: I would say the only con was dealing with varying personalities. Everyone has good days and bad days so as long as you can understand that you will not have any problems working here.

pros: They are an equal opportunity employer which makes for a diverse work environment. There is room to grow and change job positions that fit your needs.
cons: There is a feeling of hierarchy, not everyone is made to feel they are on the same playing field. There is constantly construction which increases the noise, creates working spaces that aren't ideal and at time inconveniences customers.

job_title: Customer Service Representative I in Burlington, VT
pros: Cost of health insurance, 401k is a nice match but if you leave before 3 years you don't get company contribution.
cons: Many - low wages (including confirmed gender wage disparities), micromanaging the smallest details, favortisms as not everyone is held to the same expectations.  Lack of management support and presence in the office.  Supervisor has no experience managing people and it clearly shows. Expectations are always changing leaving employees unclear of how job performance is reviewed, like audits for instance. Audits performed by senior representatives  are not double checked by management leaving Representatives either confused as we weren't given information about what was included in audit and have to spend breaks or lunch time researching the same accounts and prove our case for being marked incorrectly in audit, which can have an impact of a report in our file or lower raise in an already low paying job. Patient care is replaced with a focus on collecting money.  NOT PCI compliant, every representative is to write down credit card numbers (and shred at end of day) because company refuses to spend the money to upgrade the systems giving the reason "contract with vendors".  Morale in the office was at an all time low.

review_title: Terrible Senior Leadership - Great clinical staff to work with
pros: Excellent salary and benefits; some great MDs and other clinicians;
cons: Unrealistic expectations from senior leadership who are out of touch with what is really involved with daily management

pros: Assisting MD's in the care of SICU & PACU patients was one of the most rewarding careers I have ever had.
cons: Emotions tug & pull as you fight tears after losing a very sick or injured patient & your heart can feel for their family.

pros: Has a good benefits package
cons:
The acuity tool is outdated
Because it is so busy, nurses bullying the LNA is very common and it quite often is subtle and highly under reported. There are a lot of cliques with the nurses and LNA staff. Even though there is the window dressing of the code of conduct, that pretty much is a legal indemnification clause, that is it. I have not seen an organizationall wide campaign against this.

pros: Benefits kick in right away and are great! Most employees are great to work with.
cons: Within your 90 day orientation if your manager doesn't like you they literally need no reason to terminate your employment. Just saying you "don't fit" is all they need to say.

review_title: Hospital not synomous with caring company
job_title: Supply Chain Services in Burlington, VT
pros: Good Health benefits. Decent starting time off.
cons: Like all other companies they mostly care about the bottom line and not for the well being of their lower rung employees (non-medical staff). No room for growth with ridiculously low wages. Even after you have been here for 25+ years don't expect a wage over $17 an hour.

job_title: Field Service Technician in Jacksonville, FL
pros: If you into outdoor winter activities vermont maybe for you. Friendly staff.
cons: In my job field they took away further advancement. One of the reasons I quit I cpuslnt go any further up the ladder.

pros: Good nurse to patient ratios, good benefiits, 12 hr shifts (can be pro or con.)
cons: You are just another number to them. Had really awful managers at the time, this is obviously variable by unit. You are always being pointed out for errors and areas to improve, rarely praised for all the hard work you do there.

pros: Pleasant working conditions, adequate reports at change of shift made, excellent coordination and cooperation among staff, careful placement for sitter/patient compatibility throughout the facility.
cons: Occasionally, a patient may be very difficult to work with, at times without self-knowledge of their own words/actions.

pros: Patient centered care.  Great co-workers, excellent tuition reimbursement.
cons: Parking is awful.  You have to ride the big yellow school bus and depending where you are assigned this can be a 30" ride.  There can be a lack of transparency in the organization.

review_title: Great place to grow in your professional career.
pros: Great employee benefits, friendly staff, overall sense of community.  Hospital encourages you to continue to grow as a professional and promote lifelong learning for the benefit of the patient and staff.  Many leadership opportunities.  This is my first job out of college and I'm very proud to be working here.
cons: Parking situation could be an issue if you were just out of walking distance, but still in Burlington.

pros: The culture is unlike any other hospital that I have worked for. It truly is a patient and family centered environment. I also loved that they are so environmentally minded. I felt very supported in learning new skills and encouraged by management to grow as a professional. The health benefits and retirement match were great!
cons: I only wish that I did not have to move out of the area. I think it is a great hospital.

pros: Great place for a new grad, since it is a teaching hospital. Very strong union representation. Free parking on campus for night/evening workers. Kitchen open 24 hours. 24/7 provider presence.
cons: Must shuttle ~15 minutes when working day shift, seniority is EVERYTHING. It controls scheduling and time off. If you're a new grad, expect to "earn you place" when it comes to logistics like the ones listed.

pros: Wonderful leadership.  Good managers.  Unionized.  Competitive pay and benefits or Vermont.  Awesome atmosphere as it is a teaching hospital for University of Vermont.  The staff who work here are amazing at every level.  They care about their patients.
cons: Always political issues in every healthcare setting.   Not too bad here.

review_title: Wonderful staff and overall management team is very forward thinking
pros: Benefits are great, employee engagement is a high priority. Resources are provided to make changes and keep up with industry. VERY patient focused.
cons: Long term management team in my department that did not welcome outsiders. Little support from EAP or HR to acclimate to culture.

pros:
Your boss is 
A pager jobs are somwhat random and are able to work in all parts of the hospital
cons: We work with Bosnians that think they are not doing their job right if they are not giving you a hard time. Sometimes feels like I am working in a elementary school playground with all the childish office drama.

review_title: Very Disappointing Establishment to Work for
pros:
Good benefits
Nice people to work with
cons:
High turnover rate
Pay is way below national average for nurses
Cost of living is higher than national average
No differentials for higher degrees

pros: Lots of different areas to work in, good benefits, good pay.
cons: Very "who you know" and upper management is very insulated from the work areas and staff.

pros:
The organization provides employees with the training and resources that you need to succeed.
It is clear that they invest time to ensuring that leaders are able to lead effectively.
Everyone in the company really wants to good and help our community.
Benefits are incredible.
cons: No cons that I can think of.

pros: Strong union has your back. Great coworkers.
cons:
We had to strike to get a decent raise. Previous years raises were paltry yet they keep adding administration positions in the $700k to 1 million range. 
Lowly employees like RNs park off site and take shuttle buses to work.

review_title: A good organization to work for.
job_title: Staff Nurse III in Burlington, VT
pros: Caring management and descent benefits.
cons: There is a gap between what upper management sees as a need for clinical practice and what clinician see as a need.  Not a very effective communication between levels of management and staff.

review_title: A great Place for Employment - FAHC
job_title: Laboratory Charge Tech in Burlington, VT
pros: FAHC has great benefits from insurance and retirement to tuition reimbursement.
cons: Employees on the day shift have to park off-campus and get shuttled in to work.

job_title: Critical Care Transport EMT in Burlington, VT
pros: Benefits are great, and the opportunities for advancement are available. Education reimbursement and continuing education opportunities are fantastic.
cons: Often the only place for specialist to work, limiting your ability to go elsewhere locally for career advancement

pros: great employee wellness focus, internal candidates for open positions usually given priority, great benefits
cons: a lot of grandfathered management, not much management oversight so friendships and personal feelings about employees can take precedence over policy

job_title: Patient Account Representative in Burlington, VT
pros: Health incentives and rewards, free emotional intelligence and crucial conversation seminars, constant employee appreciation, community discounts, great health benefits at low cost
cons: Low wage, old school mentality in offices, college education doesn't always increase your pay, "old boys club" in office hinders growth in younger generation

pros: Great work-life balance and overall health-conscious and mindful culture.
cons: Combined time off is not beneficial for all employees. Having to use CTO time for holidays and days when administrative offices are closed is ridiculous.

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Burlington, VT
pros: I thought it was a good work environment and I had great health benefits.
cons: There was no on-site parking, you have to be shuttled to work.

review_title: It was a real eye opener and good learning experience
job_title: Patient Care Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: coworkers are great and keep a high moral, they are supportive and helpful
cons: There is a lot of disorganization and it can get pretty hectic, if that's what you like then it can be a good thing

review_title: All About Money and Power, Fear and Greed
pros: Some fantastic health care workers, awesome patients, good pay
cons: There are some horrible, abusive supervisors, some very greedy, unethical doctors, and a Human Resources Department that is totally corrupt. Watch your own back no one else will.

pros: Supportive coworkers who genuinely want to see you succeed! I’ve made some really great friends working here. And the patients I’ve worked with are incredible — so thankful and eager to improve.
cons: Limited hours available to per diem employees (though this is the nature of the position)

job_title: Nutrition Care Representative in Burlington, VT
pros: Good culture, Benefits, convenient location, good reputation. This is the meaningless sentence that makes me reach my twenty word minimum.
cons: Not enough Parking, hierarchical in nature (doctors and nurses think that you're worthless), nutrition department is remedial, not many fulfilling jobs available - most are administrative paper-pushers

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Burlington, VT
pros: We have some of the best staff who do their utmost to care for their patients.
cons: The compensation is below average for the cost of living.

review_title: Good place to develop your skills
pros: Academic institution with a broad range of specialties. Wonderful place to raise a family.
cons: Respect for nursing is lacking, compensation compared to cost of living is poor.

pros:
location
students
community
easy to park

review_title: Its a great place to work in the area.

pros: It's nice job with good benefits. Being in a larger department means you can be flexible with your shift if something comes up
cons: Sometimes patients can be difficult, but thats just part of the job.

review_title: Work/ life balance is part of the culture
pros: This is an organization of highly skilled professionals that are held to a high level of accountability; I feel honored to work at the University of Vermont Medical Center.
cons: Not everyone has onsite parking.

job_title: LNA Per Diem Oncology in Burlington, VT
pros: Good co-workers, they work really hard.
cons: As a per diem the pay is not that good and you feel like it's a big corporation.

review_title: Caring for an increasingly chronically sick post operative orthopedic and urology patients.
pros: The health benefits along with coworkers

pros:

pros: Great friendly atmosphere and great with their employees. They have awesome benefits with health and discounts within the community. They have great pay and overtime compensation.
